Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Wide-Area Control of Large Power Systems Using Distributed Synchrophasors: Where Network Theory Meets Power System Dynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective

This proposal strives for novel and transformative approaches to investigate and validate the highly pertinent problem of wide-area damping control of large-scale electric power systems using synchronized phasor measurements. Following the Northeast blackout of 2003, tremendous research efforts have been devoted to the visualization and postmortem analyses of Synchrophasors, leading to a formative understanding of how this technology may be used for dynamic health monitoring of complex power system networks. However, no rigorous research has yet been done to transition from monitoring to the next phase - namely, feedback control. This project will make a step towards building such control systems using a novel ?inversion? framework that allows Synchrophasor-based damping control designs, developed for reduced-order power systems, to be inverted to local excitation controllers in actual higher-order power systems. Fundamental ideas of circuit theory and network optimization will be used as the foundational thoughts for this development, combined with cumulative thoughts from graph theory and nonlinear control.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of this research will be in establishing an altogether new application area of the Synchrophasor technology through its integration with control theory and network science. Power system protection engineers will benefit tremendously from this work in extracting information from phasor data to control the dynamic stability margins of their systems following large disturbances.

Broader Impacts

The broader impact of this project will be in providing a much-needed, timely infusion of control theoretic ideas to advance emerging research on phasor-integrated next-generation smart power grids. Research results will be broadcast through journal publications, educational field trips, conference tutorials and workshops with invited speakers from the Research Triangle Park. Undergraduate research for minority engineering students will be actively promoted via the FREEDM Systems Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a suite of control designs for very large-scale power system networks using distirbuted high-resolution sensor measurements called Synchrophasors. The approach for designing these controllers
involves three precise steps, namely - 1. Model Reduction, where phasor data are used to identify second-order models of the oscillation clusters of a power system, 2. Aggregate Control, where state-feedback controllers are designed to achieve a desired closed-loop transient response between
every pair of clusters, and finally 3. Control Inversion, where the aggregate control design is distributed and tuned to actual realistic controllers at the generator terminals until the inter-area responses of the full-order power system matches the respective inter-machine responses of the reduced-order system. Although a general optimization framework is needed to formulate these three steps for any n-area power system, we have specifically showed that model reference control (MRC) can be an excellent choice to solve this damping problem when the power system consists of two dominant areas, or equivalently one dominant interarea mode. The designs have also been extended to multiple-areas by means of structured projection based control designs. Results have been verified using both offline power system models and real-time hardware-in-the-loop models in real-time digital simulators.

Theoretical methods for system identification of large-scale power systems were developed as the first step of the project. Two different types of identification algorithms had to be developed in order to suit the different dynamic model structure and oscillation patterns of the US west coast and east coast. Clustering in the western grid gives rise to distinctly visible inter-area oscillations in power flows following small disturbances in the grid. We developed efficient signal processing algorithms by which these oscillations could be theoretically characterized in terms of their damping and natural frequencies. The phasor responses on the east coast grid, lacked such oscillatory nature due to the absence of clustering. The dominant feature in these PMU data were more exponential than oscillatory. Hence, slightly different sets of signal processing tools had to be developed for handling these datasets. Both the east coast and west coast data were subjected to rigorous filtering methods to eliminate measurement noise before these signal processing algorithms could be used to extract their oscillation properties.

An integrated cyber-physical research testbed was developed at the PI’s lab at NC State. The physical layer of this testbed comprised of the real-time digital simulators, and hardware in loop Phasor Measurement Units from multiple vendors such as Schweitzer Engineering Lab, ABB, and General Electric. All of these PMUs were integrated directly with the digital ports of the RTDS via ribbon cables. The PMUs were synchronized to each other using a central GPS clock. All the PMUs were connected to a single phasor data concentrator supplied by Schweitzer Engineering Lab. Later in the project, some of the PMUs were shifted to a software phasor data concentrator as that offers higher speed processing, which is important for real-time control actions. The cyber layer of the testbed was made of a local fiber optic communication network that connects the three campuses of NC State University, Duke University, and University of North Carolina Chapel Hill. Overlaid on top of this fiber network is a cloud computing environment called ExoGENI. Virtual computing units, often referred to as virtual machines of VMs in the project, can be created on demand in this ExoGENI cloud. The VMs can be connected to each other for data sharing using software defined networks such as Internet2.

The final task was to extend the distributed estimation laws to distributed control. Linear quadratic regulator (LQR) control laws were implemented using the VMs in ExoGENI. A sparse LQR design was used so that the VMs can avoid all-to-all communication, as described above. The computed control signals were communicated back from ExoGENI to the power system model in RTDS using the analog input channels of the simulator. The physical meaning of the control signals is the excitation voltage signal for the synchronous generators that can be used to excite power system stabilizers installed in the excitation control circuit of these generators. Several experiments were done to ensure that the closed-loop hardware-in-loop RTDS-ExoGENI set up is functioning properly. Successful damping control results were obtained using high-speed communication between the RTDS and ExoGENI, and between the VMs inside ExoGENI. The sensitivity of the control performance on artificially injected network delays was tested using a different set of experiments. Experimental results were tabulated and reported in the form of a conference paper.
